questions.text: As per NMC rules, if any request is made for medical records, the documents shall be issued within the period of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

As per the NMC Registered Medical Practitioner (Professional Conduct) Regulations, 2023:

  • Every self-employed RMP must maintain medical records of inpatients for 3 years from the last date of contact.
  • If a request for medical records is made by the patient, an authorized attendant, or a legal authority, it must be:
    • Acknowledged promptly
    • Supplied within 5 working days

This applies to records managed by individual RMPs or by institutions.

Explanation of Other Options:

48 hours (Option B): Too short; may be mandated for emergency medico-legal requests but not standard record release.

24 hours (Option C): Unfeasible for routine release, especially in institutional setups.

7 days (Option D): Exceeds the NMC's prescribed limit; not compliant with current regulations.

Key Takeaway:

As per NMC 2023 regulations, requested medical records must be supplied within 5 working days, reinforcing patient rights and documentation standards.

questions.text: One of the following may not amount to professional misconduct
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Professional misconduct refers to acts that are considered disgraceful, unethical, or dishonourable when judged by peers in the medical profession.

  • Dichotomy, covering, and adultery are explicitly listed as professional misconduct in standard ethical codes.
  • However, advertisement in limited, specific contexts (e.g., announcing a new clinic or change of address) is permissible, and thus does not always constitute misconduct.
  • Repeated or misleading advertising may still be considered ethical negligence, but not automatically misconduct.

Explanation of Other Options:

Dichotomy (Option A): Fee-splitting-considered professional misconduct under NMC regulations.

Covering (Option B): Enabling unqualified practice-professional misconduct.

Adultery (Option D): Abuse of trust/position-classified as professional misconduct.

Key Takeaway:

Advertisement, when done within ethical limits (e.g., clinic opening), may not amount to professional misconduct, unlike dichotomy, covering, or adultery.

choices.text: Even if he does not give consent

questions.text: A patient suffering from a contagious disease should be treated
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the case of contagious or communicable diseases, treatment may be legally provided even without the patient’s consent in order to protect public health and safety.

  • The right to life and liberty (Article 21) of others may outweigh the individual's right to refuse treatment.
  • This legal provision ensures the containment of epidemics and protects the larger community from infection.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • Article 21 of the Constitution ensures protection of life and personal liberty, which includes reasonable public health restrictions.
  • Consent may be bypassed in the public interest, particularly during epidemics or outbreaks.
  • Relevant laws:
    • Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897
    • Disaster Management Act, 2005
    • Indian Constitution - Article 21

Explanation of Other Options:

Implied consent (Option A): Applies during routine clinical exams-not adequate for contagious disease control.

Expressed consent (Option B): Normally required, but can be overridden in public health interest.

Written consent (Option C): Preferred in elective procedures, but not mandatory in public health emergencies.

Key Takeaway:

Consent is not required for treatment of patients with contagious diseases when public health is at risk, as per legal and constitutional provisions.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child staying in a hostel suddenly develops severe abdominal pain and is rushed to the hospital. His parents are not available. The hostel warden signs the form for emergency treatment. What is this legal principle called?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In emergencies involving minors, when parents or legal guardians are not available, consent can be given by a responsible adult who is temporarily entrusted with the child.

This legal concept is known as the doctrine of loco parentis, which allows:

  • Teachers, wardens, or caretakers to provide valid consent on behalf of the child in urgent situations.
  • Emergency medical care to proceed without waiting for parental consent.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • Loco parentis means "in place of the parent."
  • Applicable only when:
    • There is immediate risk to life or health,
    • Legal guardians are unavailable, and
    • The consenting adult is responsible for the child's care.
  • This principle balances child safety with legal and ethical obligations in emergency scenarios.

Explanation of Other Options:

Inheritance (Option A): Refers to the succession of property, irrelevant to emergency medical consent.

Paternity dispute (Option C): Legal conflict over biological parentage-not related here.

Maintenance of the child (Option D): Pertains to financial/legal responsibility-does not apply to emergency consent.

Key Takeaway:

In emergencies involving children, consent can legally be obtained from a responsible adult under the doctrine of loco parentis.

choices.text: Severe warning to the RMP by the medical council
Permanent erasure of the name of the RMP from the medical register

questions.text: The term 'Professional Death Sentence' denotes-
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The term Professional Death Sentence refers to the permanent removal (erasure) of a Registered Medical Practitioner’s (RMP’s) name from the State or National Medical Register by the Medical Council.

  • This is the harshest disciplinary action a medical council can take against a doctor.
  • It is imposed in cases of gross medical negligence, unethical conduct, or serious professional misconduct.
  • This action bars the doctor from practicing medicine permanently.

Explanation of Other Options:

Rigorous imprisonment (Option A): Can only be ordered by a court, not a medical council.

Death penalty (Option B): Legal punishment unrelated to medical disciplinary action.

Severe warning (Option C): A disciplinary step, but not equivalent to permanent removal.

Key Takeaway:

Permanent removal of an RMP's name from the register for gross misconduct is termed a Professional Death Sentence in medical ethics.

questions.text: Repeated advertisement in the newspaper by a medical practitioner is an example of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Infamous conduct includes actions considered disgraceful or dishonourable in the profession, and repeated advertisements in newspapers fall under this category.

  • As per medical ethics, a Registered Medical Practitioner (RMP) may only advertise under restricted circumstances, such as:
    • Opening a new practice
    • Shifting clinic location
    • Acquiring a new qualification
  • However, repeated newspaper advertisements are prohibited and considered unethical and unprofessional.
  • The NMC Professional Conduct Regulations classify such acts as infamous conduct, warranting disciplinary action.

Explanation of Other Options:

Criminal negligence (Option A): Involves gross incompetence or reckless conduct leading to harm or death.

Privileged communication (Option B): Legally protected disclosures made in good faith to authorities, not related to advertisements.

Civil negligence (Option D): Involves breach of duty causing harm; patient may claim monetary damages.

Key Takeaway:

Repeated newspaper advertisements by doctors are unethical and amount to infamous conduct, punishable by the Medical Council.

questions.text: The Declaration of Oslo is related to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Declaration of Oslo, adopted by the World Medical Association (WMA), provides ethical guidelines for physicians regarding induced or therapeutic abortion.

  • It emphasizes that abortion may be performed only where permitted by law, and that a physician's freedom of conscience must be respected.
  • This declaration acknowledges the ethical complexities surrounding abortion and provides a framework for physicians to make decisions aligned with medical ethics and local laws.

Explanation of Other Options:

Torture (Option A): Addressed under the Declaration of Tokyo, which prohibits physician participation in torture.

Human Experiment (Option B): Governed by the Declaration of Helsinki, focusing on ethical research involving human subjects.

Hunger Strike (Option D): Covered under the Declaration of Malta, outlining physicians' duties when managing hunger-striking detainees.

Key Takeaway:

The Declaration of Oslo provides ethical guidance on therapeutic abortion, balancing legal frameworks and physician conscience.

questions.text: Criminal negligence by a Registered Medical Practitioner is punishable under Section 106(1) of BNS for a maximum imprisonment of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Under Section 106(1) of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhitha (BNS), 2023, criminal negligence by a Registered Medical Practitioner (RMP) during the performance of a medical procedure is specifically addressed:

  • If a registered medical practitioner causes death by a rash or negligent act, not amounting to culpable homicide, the maximum punishment is 2 years imprisonment and fine.
  • For non-medical persons, the punishment under the same section is up to 5 years imprisonment.
  • This differential treatment recognizes the complexity and risk inherent to medical procedures.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • The term "Registered Medical Practitioner" refers to doctors registered under the National Medical Commission Act, 2019, either in the National Medical Register or State Medical Register.
  • This provision ensures accountability while acknowledging medical risk during professional conduct.
  • The BNS replaces IPC (Indian Penal Code) and came into force in 2023.

Explanation of Other Options:

1 year (Option A): Punishment for medical negligence under BNS is longer-this option underestimates it.

3 years (Option C): Not specified in BNS; does not apply to RMPs under Section 106(1).

5 years (Option D): This is the punishment limit for general persons, not RMPs.

Key Takeaway:

Under BNS Section 106(1), criminal negligence by a Registered Medical Practitioner during treatment is punishable by up to 2 years imprisonment and fine.

choices.text: Director of Medical and Health Service

questions.text: Disciplinary control over Registered Medical Practitioners is under
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The State Medical Council is the statutory body responsible for exercising disciplinary control over Registered Medical Practitioners (RMPs) at the state level:

  • It investigates allegations of professional misconduct or ethical violations.
  • The council may issue warnings or order penal erasure (temporary or permanent removal of the RMP from the state medical register).
  • Although the Medical Council of India (now NMC) also has regulatory authority, primary disciplinary actions begin at the state level.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • The Indian Medical Association (IMA) is a voluntary organization; it cannot take legal disciplinary action.
  • Disciplinary actions include suspension, removal, or warnings based on the severity of misconduct.
  • Penal erasure is also known as the "Professional Death Sentence" if permanent.

Explanation of Other Options:

Director of Medical and Health Service (Option A): Has administrative authority but not disciplinary control over RMP registration or misconduct.

Health Secretary of State Government (Option B): Involved in health policy but does not hold direct disciplinary power over RMPs.

Indian Medical Association (Option D): A professional body without statutory powers to enforce disciplinary action.

Key Takeaway:

State Medical Councils are legally empowered to take disciplinary action against RMPs for professional misconduct.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a principle of medical ethics
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The four fundamental principles of medical ethics are:

  • Autonomy: Respect for the patient's right to make their own decisions.
  • Beneficence: Obligation to act in the best interest of the patient.
  • Non-maleficence: Do no harm to the patient.
  • Justice: Fair and equitable treatment of all patients.

Consent is an essential component of ethical and legal medical practice, but it is not one of the four foundational principles of medical ethics. Instead, it stems from the principle of autonomy.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • Consent is a legal and ethical requirement derived from respect for autonomy.
  • The four pillars form the foundation for bioethical reasoning in clinical situations.
  • These principles guide physicians in balancing care, risk, and fairness.

Explanation of Other Options:

Non-maleficence (Option B): A core principle that emphasizes avoiding harm to the patient.

Beneficence (Option C): Refers to promoting the patient’s well-being.

Justice (Option D): Implies fair allocation of healthcare resources and impartial treatment.

Key Takeaway:

Consent is not one of the four fundamental principles of medical ethics; it arises from the ethical principle of autonomy.

Reference: Beauchamp TL & Childress JF, Principles of Biomedical Ethics; also summarized in: The Medic Portal - Medical Ethics Overview.

questions.text: All the following are functions of State Medical Council except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The State Medical Council (SMC) is responsible for maintaining professional standards and registration within a specific state. Its major roles include:

  • Maintaining the medical register of all RMPs in the state.
  • Issuing warning notices to doctors regarding misconduct.
  • Taking disciplinary action against doctors found guilty of professional misconduct.

However, recognition of medical qualifications is not within the jurisdiction of the SMC. This function lies with the National Medical Commission (NMC) under the NMC Act, 2019 (previously the role of the Medical Council of India).

  • Disciplinary actions may include temporary or permanent removal from the medical register.
  • SMC ensures that only ethically practicing, qualified RMPs remain registered in the state.
  • Recognition and standardization of medical education is a central function of the NMC.

Explanation of Other Options:

Maintaining medical register (Option A): Core function of SMC to regulate the list of active practitioners.

Issuing warning notice (Option B): SMC issues warnings for minor breaches before proceeding to disciplinary action.

Disciplinary control on doctors (Option C): SMC can suspend or erase a doctor's name for professional misconduct.

Key Takeaway:

Recognition of medical qualifications is the responsibility of the National Medical Commission, not the State Medical Council.

questions.text: The modernised versions of the Hippocratic Oath comprise the
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Declaration of Geneva, issued by the World Medical Association (WMA), is a modern restatement of the Hippocratic Oath adapted for contemporary medical ethics. It emphasizes key ethical principles including:

  • Respect for human life
  • Maintaining patient confidentiality
  • Practicing medicine with conscience and dignity
  • Prioritizing patient welfare above all

It reflects the physician's commitment to humanitarian values in a global and modern context.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • Adopted in 1948 by the WMA and revised multiple times to reflect evolving ethical standards.
  • Widely adopted across medical schools and institutions globally.
  • Promotes professional integrity and patient-centered care.

Explanation of Other Options:

Declaration of Sydney (Option A): Addresses the definition of death, including brain death.

Declaration of Venice (Option C): Deals with ethical issues surrounding terminal illness and end-of-life care.

Declaration of Istanbul (Option D): Focuses on organ trafficking and transplant tourism ethics.

Key Takeaway:

The Declaration of Geneva is the contemporary ethical oath for physicians, replacing the classical Hippocratic Oath.

choices.text: At the will of the person
Person incapable of making their will
Against the will of the person
Against the will of the parents

questions.text: 'Non voluntary euthanasia' means
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Non-voluntary euthanasia refers to the scenario where a person is unable to make or express their decision regarding euthanasia, and consent is therefore neither obtained nor refused.

  • This typically applies in cases like irreversible coma, persistent vegetative state, or patients with profound congenital or acquired cognitive impairments.
  • The decision is made by caregivers or legal guardians, based on what is perceived to be in the patient's best interest.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • Voluntary euthanasia: Done with patient's consent.
  • Involuntary euthanasia: Done against patient's will.
  • Passive euthanasia: Withdrawal of life-support measures.
  • Active euthanasia: Administration of lethal agents to cause death.
  • Passive non-voluntary euthanasia is legally permitted in India under strict Supreme Court guidelines.

Explanation of Other Options:

At the will of the person (Option A): Defines voluntary euthanasia, not non-voluntary.

Against the will of the person (Option C): Refers to involuntary euthanasia.

Against the will of the parents (Option D): Not a recognised euthanasia classification in medical ethics.

Key Takeaway:

Non-voluntary euthanasia is applied when the patient cannot consent due to conditions like coma or severe brain damage.

questions.text: A 19-year-old patient presented to the emergency with altered sensorium. A non-contrast CT revealed hydrocephalus, requiring urgent neurosurgical intervention. The patient had nobody accompanying him or any identity proof. Under which of these sections of Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhitha can the neurosurgeon perform the procedure without obtaining an informed consent from a guardian?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Section 30 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhitha (equivalent to Section 92 IPC) allows medical professionals to proceed with life-saving treatment in good faith when the patient is incapable of giving consent and no guardian is available.

  • This protects doctors from legal liability when acting in the best interest of the patient during emergencies.
  • The act must be done solely for the benefit of the individual and in good faith.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • Section 25 BNS: Related to acts done with consent, not relevant when no consent is possible.
  • Section 27 BNS: Applies to actions for benefit of minors or persons of unsound mind, by guardian's consent.
  • Section 28 BNS: Covers invalid consent under fear, misconception, or incapacity.
  • Section 30 BNS: Allows emergency action without consent if patient cannot consent and no guardian is accessible.

Explanation of Other Options:

Section 25 (Option A): Requires express or implied consent-does not apply in unconscious, unaccompanied patients.

Section 27 (Option B): Refers to minors or unsound individuals where guardian consent is available.

Section 28 (Option C): Invalidates consent taken under fear or misconception-not applicable here.

Key Takeaway:

In medical emergencies where consent cannot be obtained, Section 30 BNS permits doctors to act in good faith for the patient's benefit.

choices.text: Implied term of contract between doctor and patient

questions.text: Professional secrecy is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Professional secrecy refers to the obligation of a doctor to keep patient information confidential. This duty is an implied term of the contract between the doctor and the patient, and breaching it without valid reason can result in legal action for damages.

  • It is based on the trust and confidence that the patient places in the physician.
  • Disclosure without patient consent, unless under legally valid exceptions, is considered a breach of this trust.

Circumstances where a doctor can disclose patient information:

Explanation of other options:

Legal responsibility (Option A): While professional secrecy can lead to legal consequences if breached, it originates from contractual obligation.

Ethical responsibility (Option B): Ethical principles support it, but it's not solely an ethical issue-there's a legally binding contract through implied contract.

Social responsibility (Option C): Not a formal term under medico-legal responsibility; doesn't hold professional accountability.

Key Takeaway:

Professional secrecy is an implied contractual duty of the doctor, with specific exceptions allowed under law and ethical obligations.

choices.text: Certificate issued to a government employee
Certificate issued to a poor patient
Certificate issued to a psychiatric patient

questions.text: A doctor should not take fees for issuing the following
questions.solution:
Explanation:

When a death occurs due to natural causes and the attending doctor is convinced of the cause, it is mandatory to issue a death certificate without charging any fees.

  • The doctor must issue the certificate irrespective of whether professional charges are paid.
  • The certificate should clearly mention the immediate cause of death (e.g., coronary thrombosis) and, if possible, the underlying cause (e.g., coronary artery disease).
  • This duty is a legal and ethical obligation, not a service for which fees can be demanded.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • Delay in issuing the death certificate is not permitted if the doctor is convinced of a natural cause.
  • Fees can be charged for other types of certificates unless exempted by institutional policy.
  • Terms like "cardiac arrest" or "heart failure" are vague and discouraged in death certification.

Explanation of Other Options:

Certificate issued to a government employee (Option A): Fee may be charged unless otherwise instructed by administrative rules.

Certificate issued to a poor patient (Option B): Discretionary-may be waived, but not legally mandated.

Certificate issued to a psychiatric patient (Option C): Fee may be charged unless waived by policy; not a statutory exemption.

Key Takeaway:

A death certificate must be issued without charging any fee when death is from natural causes and the doctor is satisfied with the diagnosis.

questions.text: A quack injects penicillin after giving a test dose. But the patient dies of anaphylactic shock. The quack can defend on the grounds of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A quack has no legal defence since they are not authorised to practice medicine.

  • All legal defences for medical negligence-such as therapeutic misadventure, medical malpractice, or novus actus interveniens-are only applicable to registered medical practitioners (RMPs).
  • Since a quack is not a qualified RMP, they cannot claim legal protection or justifications used by registered doctors.
  • Practising modern medicine without a valid qualification is itself illegal; hence, no legal defence is applicable.

Explanation of other options:

Therapeutic misadventure (Option A): Refers to an unexpected adverse outcome during proper treatment by a qualified doctor. Not applicable to a quack.

Medical maloccurrence (Option B): Describes an unavoidable mishap occurring despite due care. Again, defence is only valid for an RMP.

Novus actus interveniens (Option C): Means a new intervening act breaking the chain of causation. Not applicable when harm directly results from the quack's actions.

Key Takeaway:

No defence is available under medico-legal principles for an unqualified practitioner practising medicine.

choices.text: Don't vaccinate him, as you will be penalised
Obtain a court order and vaccinate him

questions.text: There has been an outbreak of a new strain of virus in your state and the Government has made it compulsory that every single person be vaccinated at the earliest to check the spread of the disease; but a colleague of yours who is also supposed to be vaccinated, refuses to give consent and says that he will sue you if you vaccinate him without his consent. What is the best option in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Even during public health emergencies, Article 21 of the Indian Constitution ensures protection of life and personal liberty.

  • A person cannot be forcibly vaccinated without due legal process.
  • Medical procedures without consent violate individual rights unless done under a valid law or court order.
  • In the context of communicable disease outbreaks, public interest can override individual consent but only through proper legal mechanisms.
  • Hence, vaccination must be carried out only after obtaining a court order.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • Article 21: "No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law."
  • Public health laws allow preventive actions like quarantine or vaccination during outbreaks, but they require procedural safeguards.
  • Forceful medical intervention without legal authority can lead to charges of assault or battery.

Explanation of Other Options:

Don't vaccinate him, as you will be penalised (Option A): Passive refusal delays public health action and may not satisfy legal duty.

Vaccinate him (Option B): Violates consent and constitutional rights without due process.

None of the above (Option D): Incorrect-there is a correct legal pathway (Option C).

Key Takeaway:

In public health emergencies, vaccination can be enforced legally, but only after obtaining a court order when consent is denied.

questions.text: Criminal negligence is punishable under
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Criminal negligence by a Registered Medical Practitioner or any individual is punishable under multiple sections of Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhitha (BNS), 2023, depending on the severity and outcome of the negligent act:

  • Section 106(1) BNS:
    • Pertains to causing death by negligence. (Option A ruled out)
    • Punishment: Up to 5 years imprisonment and fine.
    • If caused by an RMP during a medical procedure: Up to 2 years and fine.
  • Section 125(a) BNS:
    • Endangering human life or safety by rash/negligent act. (Option B ruled out)
    • If hurt is caused: Up to 6 months imprisonment or fine up to RS. 5,000 or both.
  • Section 125(b) BNS:
    • If grievous hurt is caused: Punishable with up to 3 years imprisonment or fine up to RS. 10,000 or both. (Option C ruled out)

These collectively cover a wide range of negligent conduct, from endangering life to causing actual injury or death.

Related Important Points and Concepts:

  • Criminal negligence involves a gross deviation from standard care.
  • Different sections apply depending on whether death, hurt, or grievous hurt occurred.
  • BNS, 2023 replaces IPC in governing medico-legal responsibilities.

Key Takeaway:

Criminal negligence under BNS 2023 is punishable based on severity of harm caused—ranging from endangering life to causing death.

questions.text: Absence of reasonable care and skill by a doctor in treating a patient, which results in harm, injury or death, is legally termed as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Professional negligence refers to failure to exercise the standard of care and skill expected from a medical professional.

  • Also known as medical malpractice, it arises from an act of commission or omission that causes damage to the patient.
  • To establish negligence, three elements must be proven:
    • Duty of care existed
    • Breach of that duty (act of omission/commission)
    • Resulting in damage or injury
  • Wrong diagnosis or wrong treatment may not always imply negligence if it was based on sound judgment.

Explanation of other options:

Wrong diagnosis (Option A): May occur due to human error or poor judgment, but not necessarily considered negligence unless it violates standard protocol.

Wrong treatment (Option B): If it results from a lack of care or failure to follow standard medical guidelines, it can be negligence; otherwise, it may be considered an honest mistake.

Refusal to accept a patient (Option C): Doctors have the right to accept/reject patients unless refusal is based on discriminatory grounds (e.g., caste, religion), in which case, ethical/moral violations may apply.

Key Takeaway:

Professional negligence is legally defined as the failure to provide reasonable care and skill during patient management that results in harm.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient underwent laparotomy for intestinal obstruction. Two days later, he developed high-grade fever and abdominal pain. Imaging revealed a pair of surgical scissors left behind in the peritoneal cavity. Which legal doctrine is best applied to shift the burden of proof onto the surgeon?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

When a surgical instrument is left behind in the patient's body, the act speaks for itself and implies negligence.

  • Res ipsa loquitur is a Latin phrase meaning "the thing speaks for itself."
  • This legal doctrine is applied in clear-cut cases of medical negligence where:
    • The event would not normally occur without negligence.
    • The doctor or medical staff had exclusive control over the situation.
    • The patient did not contribute to the error.
  • In such cases, the burden of proof shifts from the patient (plaintiff) to the doctor (defendant).

Key conditions for application:

  1. The injury would not have occurred without negligence.
  2. The patient did not contribute to the injury.
  3. The doctor had full control over the procedure/instrument.

Explanation of other options:

Complication in surgery (Option A): Implies known risk despite proper care-not applicable when a scissor is left behind.

Therapeutic misadventure (Option B): Unforeseen outcome during treatment-not applicable when negligence is obvious.

Failure to achieve total cure (Option C): Not legally considered negligence if proper care was given.

Key Takeaway:

In situations like forgotten surgical instruments, Res ipsa loquitur allows the court to presume negligence without further proof.

choices.text: Police not under rank of sub inspector

questions.text: In a civil negligence case against a doctor who bears the onus of proof?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In civil negligence cases, the burden of proof lies with the patient (or their representative), who must demonstrate that the doctor acted negligently and caused harm.

  • Civil negligence is tried in civil court and typically seeks monetary compensation.
  • The onus is on the patient to establish the presence of all four D’s:
    • Duty - Doctor owed a standard duty of care.
    • Dereliction - There was a breach of this duty.
    • Direct causation - Breach caused injury directly.
    • Damage - Actual harm or loss resulted.
  • The standard of proof is "balance of probabilities", which is lower than the "beyond reasonable doubt" standard in criminal cases.

Explanation of other options:

Police not under rank of sub inspector (Option B): Relevant in criminal proceedings, not civil cases.

Magistrate (Option C): Presides over criminal courts; does not bear proof responsibility.

Doctor (Option D): In civil cases, the doctor may defend their care, but the burden to prove negligence lies with the complainant.

questions.text: A female has come to a gynaecologist for a hysterectomy. The doctor explains the benefits and risks of the procedure and obtains consent. This type of consent is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Informed consent involves disclosure of all essential details regarding the procedure-including diagnosis, risks, benefits, and alternatives-to allow the patient to make an autonomous and well-informed decision.

  • This is legally mandatory before any surgical or invasive procedure.
  • It must be provided in a language understood by the patient and the decision must be voluntary.
  • The patient must be mentally sound and legally an adult to give valid consent.

Explanation of other options:

Implied consent (Option A): Assumed during routine OPD visits or minor non-invasive procedures-not valid for hysterectomy.

Blanket consent (Option C): Taken at hospital admission but not specific to surgical procedures-medico-legally weak.

Emergency consent (Option D): Used when patient is unconscious or incapable, and delay would risk life-not applicable here.

Key Takeaway:

Informed consent is ethically and legally essential before performing any surgical procedure.

questions.text: A doctor who is drunk, while performing the surgery, injured a major vessel & death of the patient. This is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

When a doctor performs a procedure under the influence of alcohol, resulting in the death of a patient due to a major surgical error, this constitutes criminal negligence. This reflects gross negligence or recklessness, which goes beyond mere inadvertence and directly endangers life.

  • Criminal negligence is punishable under Section 106(1) of BNS, particularly if the act is committed by a registered medical practitioner during a medical procedure.
  • Such actions show gross lack of competence or attention and violate expected standards of care, especially when intoxication is involved.
  • The doctor in this case may face imprisonment of up to 2 years under the new BNS provisions for medical professionals.

Explanation of other options:

Civil negligence (Option A): Refers to less severe breaches resulting in claims for compensation, not punishable by imprisonment unless gross.

Therapeutic misadventure (Option C): Unpredictable adverse event without fault or negligence; not applicable here as the cause was intoxication.

Dichotomy (Option D): Unethical fee splitting between doctors; considered misconduct but unrelated to patient death or surgical error.

Key Takeaway:

Gross errors during surgery under intoxication constitute criminal negligence and are punishable under Section 106(1) BNS.

questions.text: A patient with a previous history of abdominal surgery comes to the hospital with abdominal pain and fever. An X-ray of the abdomen is shown below. This corresponds to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The doctrine of Res ipsa loquitur (Latin: "the thing speaks for itself") applies when the very nature of the incident implies negligence even without direct evidence. In this case, retention of a surgical instrument after surgery is a classic example.

  • This principle allows the plaintiff (patient) to establish negligence without needing expert medical testimony.
  • For the doctrine to apply:
    • The injury must be of a kind that does not occur in the absence of negligence.
    • The instrumentality causing harm must have been under the exclusive control of the doctor or hospital.
    • The patient must not have contributed to the harm (no contributory negligence).

Typical Examples:

  • Retained surgical instruments (as in this case)
  • Burns from X-ray therapy
  • Blood transfusion errors
  • Operating on the wrong patient or site

Explanation of other options:

Res judicata (Option B): Prevents the same dispute from being relitigated once a final judgment has been rendered.

Novus actus interveniens (Option C): A new act breaks the direct link between original action and outcome, transferring responsibility.

Vicarious liability (Option D): Holds employers accountable for negligent acts of their employees if done in the course of employment.

Key Takeaway:

Res ipsa loquitur applies when the negligence is so apparent that it speaks for itself, such as in retained instrument cases.

questions.text: After obtaining informed consent for the management of uterine fibroids, the ureter is injured intraoperatively during hysterectomy. This situation is best covered under which medico-legal doctrine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Res ipsa loquitur means, the things speak for itself. For example, operation on a wrong patient/eye/organ/limb, leaving a surgical instrument/swab in the body cavity after operation, prescription of an overdose etc. In a simple case of hysterectomy, such as indication of fibroids of uterus, a reasonable doctor is not supposed to injure the ureter. And if he injures the ureter it falls under the doctrine of 'Res ipsa loquitur'. In a complicated hysterectomy, where as in case of malignant condition of the uterus with lot of adherences to the adjoining structures such as ureter, the injury to the ureter may be excused as therapeutic misadventure.

Explanation of other options:

Novus actus interveniens (Option A): Refers to a new, intervening cause or event that breaks the causal link between the act and the injury. Not applicable here as the complication occurred within the same chain of surgical events.

Medical maloccurrence (Option B): Medicine deals with human beings, and there are many biological variations which cannot always be explained, expected or prepared for. In some cases, in spite of good medical attention and care, an individual fails to respond properly to the treatment. This is called medical mal occurrence.

Therapeutic misadventure (Option C): Involves a mishap or accident during therapy, often related to medication or procedural error, but not due to unavoidable anatomical complications during planned surgery.

questions.text: patient is brought to the casualty with life-threatening injuries and is unconscious. There is no time to obtain consent, and the doctor proceeds with life-saving emergency surgery. The patient later dies. Under which legal doctrine is the doctor not held responsible?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

When immediate action is needed and the patient is unable to provide consent, and no legal guardian is available, the doctor is protected under Section 30 of BNS, guided by the Doctrine of Anticipation.

  • The Doctrine of Anticipation (also referred to as "implied emergency consent") applies when:
    • The patient is incapable of giving consent.
    • Delay in treatment would endanger life or health.
    • No legal guardian or proxy is available in time.
  • In such cases, Section 30 of BNS grants immunity:
    "Nothing is an offence... if the act is done in good faith for the benefit of a person without consent, when it is impossible to obtain such consent and the action must be taken without delay."

Explanation of other options:

Res ipsa loquitur (Option B): This doctrine applies when negligence is obvious, e.g., leaving a swab inside the abdomen. It does not apply in justified emergency actions without negligence.

Doctrine of Conjugated Consent (Option C)
 Not a recognised legal or ethical doctrine in standard medicolegal texts. This is a distractor.

Doctrine of extended consent (Option D)
 Applies when a new intraoperative situation arises during a planned procedure. The original consent is extended only if the new intervention is medically appropriate and time-sensitive, not for emergencies with no prior consent.

Key Takeaway:
When urgent care must be provided and consent is not possible, the doctor is protected under the Doctrine of Anticipation and Section 30 BNS, assuming actions are taken in good faith.
